questions.question: Does the patient have a headache?
Has the patient experienced any of the following red flag symptoms?
options: Sudden and abrupt onset headache reaching maximum intensity within 5 minutes (Thunderclap headache)
New-onset headache and vomiting without other obvious cause

questions.question: In relation to this patient's headache symptoms, please identify whether any of the following red flag symptoms are present.
options: A substantial change in the characteristics of the patient' s headache
Headache that wakes them from sleep
New-onset headache and a history of malignancy, especially if the malignancy is known to metastasize to the brain (lung, breast, melanoma, kidney, bowel)
Progressively worsening headache with atypical presentation
New-onset cognitive dysfunction (e.g. problems with memory, concentration, problem-solving, speaking, understanding)
Behavioural change, appetite and energy change in children

questions.question: Does the patient also present with any of the following symptoms?
options: Pulsatile tinnitus (pulsates in time with heart beat)
New-onset headache and in someone with compromised immunity, caused, for example, by HIV or immunosuppressive drugs

questions.question: Does the patient report new-onset  TVO — that is, transient episodes of blurred vision, blackout or grey out/loss of vision,  typically precipitated by changes in posture or Valsalva manoeuvres (e.g. standing up, bending forward, coughing, or straining)?
Does the patient have binocular double vision (disappears when closes either eye)?
Does the patient have a latent or manifest squint (heterophoria or heterotropia) or uncorrected refractive error to explain the double vision?
Does the patient report separation of images increases in direction of action of a weak muscle (s) in a pattern suggestive of cranial nerve palsy?

Does the patient report new-onset  TVO — that is, transient episodes of blurred vision, blackout or grey out/loss of vision,  typically precipitated by changes in posture or Valsalva manoeuvres (e.g. standing up, bending forward, coughing, or straining)?
Does the patient have binocular double vision (disappears when closes either eye)?

Does the patient report separation of images increases in direction of action of a weak muscle (s) in a pattern suggestive of cranial nerve palsy?
Does the patient report any other visual symptoms?
Is the disc elevated?
Are any of the following eye findings observed?
options: Cotton wool spots on surface or around optic disc and affecting retina
Flame or blot haemorrhages on surface or around optic disc and affecting retina

questions.question: Are any of the following eye findings observed?
options: Obscuration of blood vessels overlying disc
Hyperaemia of small blood vessels overlying disc

questions.question: Has the patient previously been identified as having crowded or tilted optic discs, or PHOMS on OCT imaging?
Has the patient previously been identified as having white-yellow bodies within the optic disc or signs compatible with drusen on OCT?
Does the patient have crowded or tilted optic discs or PHOMS on OCT imaging, discovered at this visit?
Does the patient have white-yellow bodies within the optic disc or signs compatible with drusen on OCT, discovered at this visit?
Has there been any change in visual acuity or fields?
